Paper and Cardboard Sources:
 • Newspapers, office paper, cardboard boxes.
 • Recycling: Shredded, pulped, and reformed into new paper products.

 Glass Sources:
 • Beverage bottles, food jars.
 • Recycling: Crushed, sorted by color, melted, and molded into new glass.

 Metals (Aluminum and Steel) Sources:
 • Aluminum cans, food cans, scrap metal.
 • Recycling: Shredded, melted, and remade, saving significant energy.

 Plastics Sources:
 • Water bottles (PET), milk jugs (HDPE).
 • Recycling: Sorted by type, cleaned, melted, and reformed into pellets.

 Sources: EPA, Earth911, National Geographic, Aluminum Association.

Recycling codes, marked by triangle symbols with numbers, identify plastic types to aid in recycling. Here’s a summary:

 #1 PET (Polyethylene Terephthalate)
 • Common Uses: Water bottles, soft drink bottles.
 • Recyclability: Widely recycled, but typically only once.

 #2 HDPE (High-Density Polyethylene)
 • Common Uses: Milk jugs, detergent bottles.
 • Recyclability: Highly recyclable and durable.

 #3 PVC (Polyvinyl Chloride)
 • Common Uses: Pipes, shrink wrap.
 • Recyclability: Rarely recycled due to toxic chemicals.

 #4 LDPE (Low-Density Polyethylene)
 • Common Uses: Plastic bags, cling wrap.
 • Recyclability: Often not curbside recyclable but accepted at special facilities.

 #5 PP (Polypropylene)
 • Common Uses: Yogurt containers, straws.
 • Recyclability: Increasingly accepted for recycling.

 #6 PS (Polystyrene)
 • Common Uses: Styrofoam cups, takeout containers.
 • Recyclability: Difficult to recycle and usually not accepted.

 #7 Other (Miscellaneous Plastics)
 • Common Uses: Mixed plastics, reusable water bottles.
 • Recyclability: Not typically recycled; varies widely.

 Sources: EPA, Earth911, Plastic Pollution Coalition.

The recycling process involves a few key steps:

 Collection and Transportation
 • Description: Materials are collected from homes, businesses, or drop-off locations and transported to recycling facilities.

 Sorting
 • Description: Materials are sorted by type (paper, plastic, glass, metals) using both manual and automated processes to ensure contamination is minimized.

 Cleaning and Processing
 • Description: Recyclables are cleaned to remove labels, adhesives, and contaminants. They are then processed (shredded, melted, or pulped) into raw forms like pellets or fibers.

 Manufacturing
 • Description: The processed raw materials are used to manufacture new products, which are then reintroduced to the market.

 Selling Recycled Products
 • Description: Recycled items are sold, completing the cycle and promoting further recycling.

 Sources: EPA, Earth911, National Geographic.

Recycling has significant positive environmental impacts:

 Reduces Landfill Waste
 • Impact: Diverts waste from landfills, conserving space and reducing pollution from waste decomposition.

 Saves Energy and Natural Resources
 • Impact: Recycling materials like metals and paper uses less energy than producing new ones, conserving resources such as trees, water, and fossil fuels.

 Decreases Greenhouse Gas Emissions
 • Impact: Reduces emissions from production and landfill methane, helping mitigate climate change.

 Limits Pollution
 • Impact: Decreases air and water pollution from waste incineration and resource extraction.

 Conserves Wildlife Habitats
 • Impact: Reducing raw material extraction preserves natural habitats and biodiversity.

 Sources: EPA, National Geographic, Earth911.

Here are some interesting recycling facts and statistics:

 • Plastic Waste: In 2021, only 5-6% of the 40 million tons of plastic waste generated in the U.S. was recycled.
 • Energy Savings: Recycling 10 plastic bottles can save enough energy to power a laptop for more than 25 hours.
 • Paper Recycling: Over 50 million tons of paper were recycled in 2021, achieving a 68% recycling rate.
 • Aluminum: Aluminum can be infinitely recycled with 95% less energy than creating new aluminum from raw materials.
 • Ocean Plastic: Between 75 and 199 million tons of plastic are currently in the oceans.
 • Economic Impact: The recycling industry in the U.S. supported 681,000 jobs and generated $37.8 billion in wages in 2020.
 • Cardboard: The recycling rate for corrugated cardboard was 91.4% in 2021. 

 Sources: EPA, National Geographic, Earth911.
